story: NewsBubbly -year-old went to bed with cold symptoms and never woke upAbigail Harris, from Cheltenham, had been feeling unwell for months, but tried to shake off her symptoms before being found fitting in the early hours of the morning by her boyfriendShareCommentsByMelissa JonesAbigail OLeary:,  APR NewsAbigail had been feeling unwell for months, unknowingly suffering from a bacterial form of meningitis "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bubbly -year-old went to bed with symptoms of a cold and tragically never woke up. Abigail Harris, from Cheltenham, had been feeling unwell for months, but had tried to shake off her symptoms and carry on with le.But the estate agent had no idea she was actually suffering from a bacterial from of meningitis - a serious infections affecting the thin lining surrounding the brain and spinal cord. On March , Abigail went to hospital with a painful wrist, reports Gloucestershire Live .After being diagnosed with tendinitis, she was advised rest it, but later that same night messaged her paramedic aunt, Fiona Scarlett, about having trouble breathing. The pair discussed some of her other symptoms, before Abigail went to bed.    It marked the last time they spoke. Fiona said: She said she couldn’t drive to hospital due to her wrist hurting so I told her to get her boyfriend Kieron to take her. But she hadn’t told him how bad she felt and he’d gone to bed. She didn’t want to bother him. She said she’d try to go to sleep. We left it there. Fiona became even more concerned when her niece failed to respond to a message the next morning askingshe felt better. Abigailaposs father then rang to say she had been found fitting by her boyfriend in the early hours of the morning and rushed to hospital. Medics then discovered a rash on the inside of one of her knees while she was in intensive care. Fiona added: She was being treated for meningitis.    This was such a shock. It hadn’t even occurred to me it could be that as we don’t hear about it so much anymore. Abi did not improve with antibiotics, she was receiving expert care and it was becoming clear that things were not looking good for our girl. We kept hoping. “As the day progressed, the doctors started to prepare Abi’s mum, dad, brother and her boyfriend for the worst news. On Friday March , with all her close family and best friends nearby, Abi was declared brain dead. The next day and as per her wishes, she donated her organs to save others and she was finally allowed to rest. Abigailaposs family are sharing their heartbreaking story in a bid to stop other families suffering and to make World Meningitis Day, on April .

title: meet incredible people who overcame
story: NewsMeet the incredible people who overcame adversity to achieve greatnessEXCLUSIVE Double Olympic gold medallist James Cracknell made an incredible comeback at the Boat Race, but hes not the only “invincible” to bounce backShareCommentsByLaura Connor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJames Cracknell "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs comeback stories go, the journey from catastrophic brain injury to oldest ever winner of the brutal Boat Race takes some beating. At  years old, James Cracknell did just that when he rowed for victorious Cambridge this year. But in , he nearly died when he was hit by a petrol tanker while cycling across America, and was placed in an induced coma. The double Olympic gold medallist is not the only “invincible” to bounce back. These are just a few of the incredible people who have overcome adversity to achieve something truly special. Lee Spencer Former Royal Marine Lee survived three tours of Afghanistan only to lose his right leg after being hit by flying debris as he was helping a motorist who had crashed on the M in Surrey in . Last month, the -year-old became the fastest person to row solo and unsupported across the Atlantic in  days – breaking the able-bodied record by  days.    Lee, from Devon, says: “I want to show that you don’t have to define people by their disability, and I have done that by beating the able-bodied record. “It was such an important thing for me to sht society’s perceptions of what it means to be a disabled person.” Grace Had Grace’s injuries were so bad after a  car crash that her family were told: “Don’t hold out hope”.    Aged , she broke  bones in her body, suffered a punctured lung, split liver, bleeding spleen and failing kidneys, after clipping a kerb at mph and hitting oncoming traffic. She was in an induced coma for a month at St George’s Hospital in Tooting, south london, and had many skin grafts to her arm and thigh. After being discharged from hospital three months later, she pledged to run the london Marathon. And she did, two years later. She says: “If i’m ever on my deathbed again, i want to have no regrets.” Kate Baker Kate had a brain tumour, known as a haemangioblastoma, which doctors said would have killed her within six hoursit hadn’t been treated.    In , Kate, mum to five-year-old Max, spent six days on Queens Hospital Romford’s ‘Sahara b’ ward, and had a drain in her skull. In February, the -year-old from Colchester spent six days enduring searing heat to trek through the Sahara Desert for The brain Tumour Charity. She said: “I left hospital under a rainbow of glittery colours eternally grateful for a second crack at le.” Simon Kindleyside As Simon walked night and day to complete his -hour record-breaking London Marathon last year, he showed the world that paralysis is no bar to achievement. The dad of three, from Norfolk, got a Guinness World Record as the first paralysed person to finish the route in an exo-suit, a robotic device.    In , Simon, , was diagnosed with a neurological disorder and a glioma brain tumour, and is paralysed from the waist down. He said: “I hadn’t walked  miles in my le when i was able-bodied, so that is a massive achievement in itself.” James Rose Soldier James, , lost both his legs hen he stepped on a bomb while serving in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in November .  James, from Middlesbrough, nearly ied, and had four years of treatment for injuries including a broken pelvis. He suffered from depression after being discharged from the Army in  – but last year he won silver and gold medals in sitting volleyball and wheelchair basketball at the Invictus Games. He said: “I needed to find my mojo again.” Kiko Matthews Kiko, , from Herefordshire, was diagnosed with Cushings Disease in , a le- hreatening condition which causes tumours on the pituitary gland.  The former science teacher survived two rain tumours and a le-threatening illness to become the fastest-ever woman to row cross the Atlantic, solo and unsupported, st year – completing the epic task in  days, seven hours and  minutes. She said: “I have shown that anyone can attempt anything given the right attitude, belief and support.”  Paul Steward When he was , doctors told Paul he would never walk again when an avalanche broke his back in .  With painstaking rehabilitation and the aid of carbon fibre splints and sticks, Paul, from London, completed a full Ironman triathlon, comprising of a .mile swim, mile cycle, and a .mile walk, five years later. He ended the challenge by scaling the ft clf face he fell down at mph while skiing in La Plagne, France. Paul, now , said: “What I am most proud of is that I managed to turn a tragic event into a happy one. I have hopefully inspired a few to make le better for themselves.” Debbie OaposConnell Debbie served as a gunner in the Royal Artillery, but was discharged in  when she was thrown from a horse.  The accident shattered her collarbone, breaking it into four and leaving her with a paralysed left arm. But after ing to civilian le, the -year-old from Lincoln competed in the Invictus Games. She matched the men’s team success, winning two gold medals for cycling and two silver running medals. Debbie, who now works as a funeral director, said: “I now have the determination to pick myself up, focus and train again for a good cause – me.”

story: NewsTransgender lottery winner to spend £k on nose job and facelt to be more feminineEXCLUSIVE Former taxi driver Melissa Ede won £million on a scratch card and shes spent £, on teeth implants, lip-fillers, cheek-fillers and botox - but shes already looking ahead to her next surgeryShareCommentsByLucy Thornton:,  APR NewsMelissa Ede has already decided what shes having done next "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTransgender lottery winner Melissa Ede has booked the “next phase” of her rejuvenation and cannot wait to be “even more feminine”. The former taxi driver, who won £million on a scratch card, is about to splash out £, on a nose job and facelt. The -year-old has spent £, on teeth, lip-fillers, cheek-fillers and Botox. Mel said: “I nearly feel like a new woman. I feel more confident – but I want to be even more feminine. “There is such a change in how I look already. I looked older than my age when I announced my lottery win in . But now I think I could pass for being in my s.”    Mel spent nine hours in the dentist chair having  teeth out and replaced with implants to give her a new smile. She has also had lip-filler twice to get “pout-ier lips” and cheek-fillers “to add to perfection”. But Mel said of the latest surgery, booked for August: “I have a nose like Concorde, skiers would pay good money to come down this slope. “I was told I have amazing cheekbones and my chin is not masculine at all. But once I do the facelt, you will see my chin more.    “I want to be more gorgeous than I am. But most people would say that was an impossible task,” she added, laughing. “Before, I got looked at because I was transgender. I used to get called names. I get looked at because I’m Melissa Ede.” Yet despite spending thousands on cosmetic surgery and a new home near Hull, Mel takes it easy with her winnings. She said: “I’m the worst multi-millionaire ever. I still shop at Primark and use a box dye to do my hair.”

From there he was transported to Las Vegas for further treatment. Jonathan suffered multiple wounds and two broken bones. He will be recovering for several months. Bowie is fine and resting in his habitat and we will not euthanize him because of the accident.    Jonathan said: “There are many photographs showing me having close contact with a iety of animals when they were young or ones that I had raised. Those are from ‘the old days’. Close contact with wild exotic and native species has not been a practice in many years. My accident with Bowie was my fault. I was concerned for his welfare and did not stay focused on him. It only takes a fraction of a second for a captive wild animal to revert to their instinctual behavior. These situations occur when there is human error.” According to their website, Keepers of the Wild is a non-profit animal sanctuary that provides a le-long home to rescue animals. The animal sanctuary has been home to animals deemed either unfit for the wild or having spent too long in captivity. An investigation into the attack is underway.

title: true story worlds richest man
story: NewsTrue story of worlds richest man who refused to pay kidnapped grandsons ransomOil tycoon J Paul Getty also moaned about having to pay his own sons medical bills when he was battling a brain tumourShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsTe billionaire even moaned about paying his son, Timmys medical bills as he was dying of a brain tumour "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email J Paul Getty was one of he worldaposs richest billionaires after making his fortune in oil.But the magnate is not just famous for his wealth but also for being one of the meanest billionaires ever.He famously refused to the ransom to save his grandsonaposs le following his kidnap in .In revenge, the kidnappers cut off the teenageraposs ear and posted it to his frugal grandfather. But the frugal billionaireaposs mean streak was evident long before the famous kidnapping, which has been turned into both a film and a TV series.  The oil magnate’s love of money over family extended to his terminally ill son. Timmy’s tale is perhaps the truest reflection of Getty’s frugality. He was the son of Getty’s fth and final we Teddy Getty Gaston, who died last April aged . In her memoir, the American singer revealed the extent of Getty’s tight pockets. The American-born ­industrialist moaned about having to foot Timmy’s medical bills when he went blind from a brain tumour. While Timmy battled for his le, Getty failed to see him for four years.  The miser missed his son’s birth and, when Timmy died at the age of , Getty did not attend the funeral – sending Teddy a note apologising for being busy. Timmy idolised his father, however. In her book, Alone Together, Teddy remembers Timmy’s love for his father during his dying days in heart-breaking detail. “He was full of love for his dad,” she writes. “ He never knew he was the richest man in the world. He’d heard it but he’d say, ‘That’s what the world sees. I see him as my own darling daddy, whom I love’. How he missed Paul.” She adds: “Sometimes I sat ­quietly beside him while he seemed to be ­thinking and he’d suddenly say, ‘When will he come home  I wish I had a daddy like other boys have. Do you think he really loves me  I wish I could talk to him.’  “‘Well, let’s talk to him,’ I’d say, and we’d call Paul. He’d tell everyone then for days that he’d spoken to his father. He never asked for any material things, all he wanted was to see his dad. He never begrudged the fact that Paul never came. He was too loving… and yet in his heart he needed a father.” So Getty was as absent as he was parsimonious. Teddy never forgave him for failing toto his American home from England during Timmy’s illness, citing it as the reason for their orce in .  In letters sent in the years leading up to Timmy’s death, Teddy pleaded with her husband toand comfort their son. But he never did. Teddy wrote to Getty in : “I know now that you aren’t coming home to us, because I know you don’t want to, and so I have come to the tragic realisation that you have no real concern for Tim or me.” At that time, in , Getty was ­negotiating the groundbreaking deal to secure oil rights in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which would see him become America’s first billionaire. But not only did Getty refuse tohome – he cruelly built up  hope in his little boy’s mind. He regularly promised to visit Timmy in New York hospitals after his ­operations, but again never did so.  The Getty Oil boss was even heartless enough to complain about doctors’ bills on the phone to Teddy as Timmy lay screaming in pain in the room next door. Teddy remembers bursting into tears and hanging up the call, feeling alone and afraid as she battled the toughest years of her le without her husband. “Timmy needed his father,” she says in her memoir. “I needed him, too. In the days after Timmy’s initial brain tumour diagnosis aged six in , many members of the family, including Teddy’s brother Ware, nephews, nieces and Timmy, excitedly gathered to wait for Getty as the Queen Mary liner pulled into New York, told by the tycoon that he would be on board. But a message from the captain confirmed he had never fulfilled his promise of travelling across the Atlantic. Getty had not only failed to board the ship – he had not even bothered to let his family know.  Two days later, Timmy had to undergo one of his countless operations, hopes dashed of having daddy by his side. Later that year Getty wrote a letter from the Ritz Hotel in Paris which would be callous from a pauper, but was positively cruel from a billionaire. He said: “I hope Timmy can keep away from doctors, except for a  visit. I don’t think doctors can do much for him now, except for a check-up, and that shouldn’t be more than  unless the doctors charge on the ability to pay and not on a tarf and I avoid such doctors.” He told Teddy the money she paid for a pony to comfort Timmy must come out of her own purse.  Teddy died when he was just -years-old. But it was the abduction of his -year-old grandson, John Paul Getty III, that showed the world just what a miser J Paul really was. The free spirited -year-old was living in Rome with his father, J. Paul Getty II when he was kidnapped. He had apparently been trying to woo a Belgian go-go dancer in the Piazza Navona in Rome when he disappeared before dawn on July , . Paul was buying a comic book at a newsstand when he was abducted by three men who knocked him out by hitting him with a gun.  The men drove him to a cave in the southern part of the country and tied him up while they probed the Getty family for the hefty ransom which shockingly his grandfather refused to pay. No-one knows exactly the sequence of events but a ransom note read: Dear Mother: I have fallen into the hands of kidnapers. Don’t let me be killed! Make sure that the police do not interfere. You must absolutely not take this as a joke… Don’t give publicity to my kidnaping.” At first police didnapost believe the boy had been kidnapped but they realised it was no joke when the kidnappers called to say they would send the boyaposs mother one of her sonaposs fingers and demanded million from his grandfather.  Initially J Paul Getty reportedly refused to pay - commenting that he had  other grandchildren. He was quoted as saying that he opposed paying the kidnappers in principle, because it only encourages kidnapping as a criminal practice. The billionaire is reported to have said: “I have  other grandchildren andI pay one penny now, then I’ll have  kidnapped grandchildren.” His refusal to pay lead to devastating consequences for the teenager. John Paul was subjected to months of agonising torture and even had part of his ear cut off, which was then sent to a local paper. In early November an envelope was delivered to the Rome daily Il Messaggero,Rolling Stone reports .It contained a lock of reddish hair and a severed human ear.This is Paul’s first ear, read a typewritten note. If within ten days the family still believes that this is a joke mounted by him, then the other ear will arrive. In other words, he will arrive in little bits.apos The delivery of the ear was apparently enough for Getty Snr to agree to pay the ransom - but at a reduced rate of millionAt the time he was estimated to be worth around £bn.  But this wasnapost an act of grandfatherly compasion, J.Paul was told the ransom would be tax deductable by his accounts. Paul was finally released five months after he was first abducted. He flagged down a truck driver, who drove him to the nearest police station where officers noticed his missing ear. Following his ordeal, Paul developed an addiction to alcohol. And nine years after his released was left quadriplegic following an overdose of methadone and valium. He died, aged , in .

title: eating toilet next condoms corpses
story: NewsEating on a toilet, next to condoms or corpses - the worlds weirdest restaurantsIf you fancy dining in the dark or trying to eat while ninjas fly at you, we have just the placeShareCommentsByAmanda Killelea:,  APR NewsThe worlds largest underwater restaurant has opened in Norway "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Diners looking for an eating experience with a dference need look no more.Europe’s first underwater restaurant has recently opened in Norway with a gigantic viewing window through which you can see the ocean whilst you dine. The restaurant, called Under, is in big demand - with more than , people already booked to eat there. But it isn’t the only unusual restaurant where you can dine in style. Toilet humour - Shangai    If you can stomach it, More Than Toilet in Shanghai’s theme is, you’ve guessed it, toilet humour. The dining tables are bathroom sinks topped with glass, and the seats are of course toilets. The food is served in toilet-themed receptacles too. Milk tea is served in urinal shaped mugs, and chocolate ice cream is dished up in toilet-shaped bowls. Not one for the squeamish. Tall order - Kenya    At Giraffe Manor in Nairobi, Kenya, diners have to be happy to get up close and personal with the restaurant’s friendly resident giraffes. The herd of Rothschild giraffe’s delight in sticking their heads through the windows into the dining room whilst guests eat in the hope of being fed some tasty treats. In the dark - London  If you are scared of the dark then prepare to face your fears at Dans le Noir in London. Diners are served a surprise menu completely in the dark by visually impaired servers. The idea is that guests are taken on a complete sensory journey where they have to rely on their other senses and embrace the experience without their sight. They even have to go to the loo in the dark. Dead quiet - India  At the New Lucky restaurant in India diners break bread amongst the dead. The diner is built on graves - which the owner believes is a lucky charm. Safe sex - Thailand  Cabbages and condoms was launched in Thailand by Mechai Viravaidya. He said: You can go to any shop around Thailand and you will always find cabbages... condoms should be like cabbages which are ubiquitous and accessible to everyone.” And so the name Cabbages  Condoms was conceived. Mr Mechai believed that condoms should not be seen as taboo but as a necessity, which could save people’s lives from dangerous STIs including HIV AIDS as well as unwanted pregnancy. There are now branches in Bicester and Cheltenham - and after their meals diners are encouraged to take free condoms home with them rather than after dinner mints. Plane crazy - Bolton  In a quiet corner of Bolton sits a Boeing  which houses the restaurant aptly named Steaks on a Plane. The wings have been removed and the plane has been cut in half - but the cockpit is still intact and tables and chairs have replaced the airline seats. The quirky restaurant has been attracting diners from across the country since it took off in . Chop and drop - New York Don’t expect a peaceful meal at Ninja New York. Here Ninjas fly in from all directions whilst you eat, creeping out of cupboards or jumping right in front of you as you nip to the bathroom. Hearty feed - Las Vegas  The heart attack grill in Las Vegas is all about guest participation. Diners - known as patients - have to dress in hospital gowns before they sit, which are handed to them by the waitresses who are dressed as nurses. Menus are prescriptions, and they feature burgers which are temptingly called the “triple bypass” and “quadruple bypass.”

story: NewsKim Jong-Un shakes hands with Vladimir Putin during historic meetingNorth Korean leader arrived in bullet-proof train to met with Russian premier Putin in Pacic city of VlaostokShareCommentsByAndrew Gilpin:,  APR Updated:,  APR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news offline video kim-meets-putin-what-expect-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:[ REV- ],video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:[ REV- ],video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussian president Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un have met for their historic first talks. The North Korean leader met Russian President at a summit designed to show that Washington is not the only power able to set the agenda on Pyongyangaposs nuclear programme. Putin wasted no time in telling Kim that he welcomes his efforts to normalise US-Koren relations - saying that Russia would like to help support efforts to resolve the North Korean nuclear standoff. But he also warned thereaposs a lot that needs to be done to develop trade ties between the countries. Putin also said that he expected Kimaposs visit to Russia would help the two countries understand how to reach settlement over the Korean peninsula and develop bilateral ties.  For his part Kim said that the summit will help jointly assess the Korean peninsula issues an coordinate their stances. He added that the talks should help better understand what Russia could do to support negotiations. Mr Kim congratulated Mr Putin on winning another six-year term in last yearaposs election. He noted that their talks will give a chance to exchange views on the situation on the Korean Peninsula.  The two men sit down together on an island off the Russian Pacic city of Vlaostok two months after Kimaposs summit with U.S. President Donald Trump ended in disagreement, cooling hopes of a breakthrough in the decades-old nuclear row. The summit in Vlaostok - the first ever between Putin and Kim - provides Pyongyang with an opportunity to seek support from a new quarter, Russia, and possible relief from the sanctions hurting its economy. For the Kremlin, the summit is a chance to show it is a global diplomatic player, despite efforts by the United States and other Western states to isolate it. Mr Kimaposs first trip to Russia comes about two months after his second summit with President Donald Trump failed because of disputes over US-led sanctions on the North. Mr Putin meanwhile wants to expand Russiaaposs influence in the region and get more leverage with Washington. We welcome your efforts to develop an inter-Korean dialogue and normalize North Koreaaposs relations with the United States, Mr Putin told Mr Kim.  But with Moscow committed to upholding sanctions until the North dismantles its nuclear programme, analysts said the summit was unlikely to produce any tangible help for Pyongyang, beyond a show of camaraderie. In an interview with Russian state television as his train made a stop off on the journey to Vlaostok, Kim said he was looking forward to useful talks. I hope that we can discuss concrete questions about peace negotiations on the Korean peninsula, and our bilateral relations, he said through an interpreter.  Making his first trip to Russia as North Korean leader, he arrived at the train station in Vlaostok on Wednesday on board an armoured train -his preferred mode of international transport. After a brief delay while the train had to be repositioned to line up with the red carpet laid out on the , he disembarked and headed in a convoy of limousines and minivans across a bridge linking mainland Vlaostok to Russky island, the summit venue.

title: cyclist left on crutches after being pushed over by biker on dundee road
story: A cyclist from the Hilltown has been left on crutches after he was allegedly pushed off his bike by a motorcyclist.David Matthews had ventured out on his bicycle for only the second time this year when the incident happened on Emmock Road. vw, px"  The -year-old said he had sustained a hairline fracture to his pelvis and cuts and bruises on his body during the incident on Sunday afternoon.David said he had been passed by a group of three motorcyclists on scrambler-style bikes.He said the first bike had been close to him before the second passed “even closer” at a speed of more than mph.When the third bike approached David, he alleges the rider pulled up alongside him before pushing him over.He said: “I must have been doing about mph on my bike.“When the third rider came past I felt the guy’s hand – I assume it was his left hand because he came past me on the right.“When I hit the road I smacked down on to it.“My helmet did its job, but I had ringing in my ears and I was a bit woozy for a couple of minutes.“Initially I didn’t think I was too badly injured – a few cuts and scrapes – but as time went on I was in more pain.“It was a stupid thing for the motorcyclist to have done. I reckon they must have been going at mph when they came past me.”David was taken to AE at Ninewells where his injuries were scanned.He added: “I went back to Ninewells Hospital on Monday morning to get the results.“I have a hairline fracture at the lowest point of my pelvis.“I’m on crutches at the moment and taking painkillers .“It looks like I’ll be off my bike for a few months.“A number of motorists stopped to make sure I was OK before the emergency services arrived.”A spokesman for Police Scotland said: “We attended Emmock Road, near Balnuith Farm, Angus, at around pm on Sunday after a cyclist came off his bicycle and sustained head and back injuries.“He was taken to hospital for treatment but was not seriously injured.”

title: german book taken out during ww2 returned to north east library after seven decades
story: Librarians at a north-east school were astonished to discover an overdue book had been handed back – more than  years after it was first loaned.The German language book Sprechen Sie Deutsch! by Oscar Burkhard was ed to Peterhead Academy’s library last week.It was originally taken out by one of the school’s pupils back in the s – around the time of the Second World War. vw, px"  An Aberdeenshire Library service spokeswoman said: “A book was ed to Peterhead Academy Library last Thursday.“That’s not an unusual occurrence, other than that the book, Sprechen Sie Deutsch! by Oscar Burkhard, published in , was taken out by a pupil in the s.“Unfortunately the issue sheet on the inside cover has been ripped so we don’t have an exact date.#A family ed it to the school, having been clearing out a relative’s house, and had decided toit to the library.“It looks well used, with notes in pencil in the margins and the borrower had attempted to stick some pages back in the book.“Vielen Dank! ” vw, px"  The inside of the book states that the book is the property of the Aberdeenshire Education Committee.It adds that the pupil to whom the book has been issued will be held responsible for its safe keeping and good condition and required to replace itever lost or damaged.The discovery is the latest in a series of overdue books across the north-east finally being ed decades after they were due – but looks likely to take the record for the longest overdue date.Staff at Aberdeen Central library were left in “disbelief” after a book that had been overdue for  years was finally ed.The copy of A Window in Thrums by Peter Pan author JM Barrie had last been seen on the Central Library’s shelves back in .The book was spotted by a member of the public in a charity shop in London and was then posted back to stunned staff at the city centre library.Thankfully for the man or woman who found the book, they did not have to pay the late fees – estimated at around £,.JM Barrie’s book is one of several he set around the fictional village of Thrums, which he is believed to have loosely based on Kirriemuir in Angus, from where he originally hailed.And last year a book was ed to Ferryhill Library  years after it was due to be ed.The crime thriller A Touch of Danger was borrowed from Aberdeen Central Library four decades ago, and stamped with an original due date of December  .However, years went by and it remained absent from the shelves until it was ed anonymously to Ferryhill Library on December .The novel, by From Here to Eternity author James Jones, is about an American detective who runs into danger while operating on a Greek island.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

title: retired teacher unearths marquis family roots
story: Mark DaveyUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowA Bardic family whose Argyll roots date back more than  years is spotlighted in a new book about Highland history.A retired teacher, from Leicestershire, Steve Marquis, has researched his family’s colourful past and unearthed claimed links with Flora MacDonald.The Marquis family history also includes the Jacobite rebellions and Tarbert, Loch Fyne, where his forebears lived for more than three centuries.His grandfather, Angus Marquis, born in Tarbert in , was descended from a long line of Loch Fyne fishermen. He left the village for an apprenticeship at Govan shipyards during the First World War before heading south for Leicester in the s.Steve, , one of several Marquises still living in Leicestershire, has just published The Le and Times of The Marquis Family of Argyll.It covers the family’s long Highland history as bards, smugglers, clan warriors, rebels and fishermen, with one forebear being tacksman on the island of Cara.He was inspired by his grandparents’ lives as exiled Scots, and their tales of Highland le.Though Angus Marquis left Tarbert for a new le in the south nearly a century ago, his children and grandchildren still make summer ‘pilgrimages’ to the family’s spiritual home, tracing the buildings where the Marquises lived and their graves in Tarbert cemetery.‘It has been an interesting experience,’ said Steve. ‘I have been helped in my research by many people and have unearthed details we simply didn’t know about the Marquises who went before us.#There was always an assumption that we were Huguenots, but that appears not to be the case. We were Gaelic speakers whose roots lie deep in Scottish soil.#I discovered that we were linked to Flora MacDonald through marriage, and that our bardic traditions go right back to the s.’Until the late th century, the Marquises were known as MacMarcuis or MacMarquis, and had strong links with the MacDonalds.Angus Marquis was one of the seven children of fisherman Dugald Marquis, born in , who fathered five children by his first we, Margaret Bain, and two # including Angus # by his second, Mary McLeod.While an apprentice in Glasgow, Angus met his future we, Mary Jordan, from Furnace. Together they had five sons, including Steve’s father, George.While several of their offspring now live in America, Australia and Cornwall, most of the Marquis family settled in Leicestershire.The book is available from Steve at: stephen.marquis@ntlworld and there is a website: www.marquisfamilyhistory.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: canoodling teens blight playpark kids
story: NewsCanoodling teens blight playpark for kidsAnger at the Ayr seafront beackparkShareByEdwin Lawrence:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsTeen frolics on the chute - crime prevention boss Alec Kelly hits out "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeenagers fooling around at a playpark spoiled the fun for younger kids. An alarmed grandfather heard his nine-year-old grandson shout for help at the Ayr seafront playpark. The wee boy had gone for a shot on the £, tower complex, which has several chutes. But canoodling teens made the youngster climb over a ledge to get past them. And then they pushed him down the chute, prompting his cry for help. Grandfather Alex Kelly, who is chairman of South Ayrshire Crime Prevention Panel, said: “It was Saturday night about  o’clock and we had been for chips in Ayr. “My grandson wanted to go down to the seafront for a shot on the new tower. “I thought I would just stay in the car and let him go ahead but I could see there were a few teenagers, aged  or , hanging about. “My grandson was off and running and away up the inside of the tower. “The next thing I knew he was shouting for help at the bottom of a chute.” Alex added: “He told me what had happened and I wasn’t too happy. “I also saw a dad take his wee girl from inside the tower as she was intimidated by the older kids on it. “I didn’t want to confront the teenagers but I did phone the council. I don’t think it’s acceptable to let teenagers intimidate children in these circumstances. “There should be some kind of supervision that doesn’t involve the police, although the council seems to think the police should be involved.” Alex, of Maybole, reckons there were six young teenagers at the top of the tower, three boys and three girls. He said: “In the good old days we had park keepers to deal with this kind of thing.” A council spokesman said: We are happy that our play parks are popular, but anyone using them should act responsibly. title: dynamite plan give ayr great
story: NewsDynamite plan to give Ayr a great futureAll sorts of buildings such as Matalan, Odeon and Waterfront pub would come downShareByStephen Houston:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsBack in use - the old rail bridge would become an inner ring road "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA radical plan to rescue Ayr town centre has been published – and it’s sure to provoke astonishment. That’s exactly what the creators of the Bruce Plan want in a bid to stimulate a real future for the stricken town. The #AyrDeservesBetter campaign want people to sign up to the cause for real action. And Rob Close, chief writer of the -page document, said: “We want real action not yet another expensive consultant’s report. “We have written this for free – now we want our elected leaders to actually do something.” The details of the Bruce Plan – named after King Robert who routed English troops from Ayr – can only now be revealed. The controversial idea, devised by Rob, a Mastermind contestant and Radio  Brain of Britain finalist, involves flattening buildings throughout the centre. And that includes working businesses: ● Matalan ● Mr Basrai’s World Cuisines ● The Odeon ● Sports Direct ● The Tam o’Shanter petrol station ● The Waterfront bar restaurant Wrecking balls will also be brought in to demolish the old Orient cinema Babylon nightclub. This is a key part of the new inner ring road which would utilise the old rail bridge over the River Ayr and replace a traffic system regarded as bonkers. The railway station would finally be annexed from the old hotel and built several hundred yards south at the old Townhead yard. The group see this as “critical” to the future of Ayr. It is thought Network Rail would favour this as certain s at present cannot take the extra long trains now required on the route. The bus station would be relocated to the Matalan Sports Direct site.And the Stagecoach bus station would become part of a new culturalquarter.Rob Close, an historian and architectural author, is working closely with architect Pat Lorimer, the spokesman for #AyrDeservesBetter. Rob said: “I appreciate some may disagree and that I have made no attempt to cost it. “But the cost of doing nothing and allowing the town to crumble in the face of unrelated decisions by successive South Ayrshire Council administrations is much more of a risk – financially, socially and aesthetically. “I feel this plan begins to look like a town that many more of us will want to live in. “People can have a go at itthey wish, but at least it gives us something to focus minds on.” The -strong #AyrDeservesBetter are a think-tank of Ayr partisans. Miller Road and Fort Street would become part of the inner ring road, with the historic Sandgate largely access only. This ring would slice through the Orient cinema site, cut through the Aldi car park, the Waterside bar and into Fort Street. Seven piers of the old fishmarket railway bridge still exist and could provide the support for a new structure The Bruce Plan has drawn ideas from a  map of the town centre. Unlike some towns there are physical constraints such as the river, bridges and railway line that cannot be moved.The #ADB advocates the entire bottomend of the High Street no longer beinga shopping area, and all businessesclustered from the centre towards the top of the town, anchored by the Ayr CentralMall.Businesses in Miller Road including LA Bowl would be encouraged to relocate to the central core and for it to become largely residential again. South Ayrshire Council has already advocated demolishing the Citadel pool and sports hall and creating a new one at the Kyle Centre. The group proposes the Station Hotel becomes council offices and the railway buildings on the other side of the track to become social enterprises. #AyrDeservesBetter say the town centre developed piecemeal over the past  years without an overal plan. With  empty shops and buildings there is now need to have compression rather than an expansive retail area.Matalan or even Marks  Spencercould become tenants in the Hourstons building.Details of the Bruce Plan also call for no methadone prescriptions in the town centre. A free bus would operate to include the river and seafront and parking for the first three hours would be free. Extra parking could be created on the old Afflecks factory via Sandgate. It is mooted a public competition to re-design Burns Statue Square after the Odeon and Burns House are brought down. A cultural quarter of town would include the Gaiety Theatre, Mecca Bingo, the nightclubs of Arthur Street and the Mercure Hotel. The Plan states: “Some of the ideas for rescuing Ayr could be re-located here, such as LA Bowl and Fury’s from Nile Court.” Rob hopes the ideas can gain traction and adds: “I know such a scheme will come to fruition onlythe council, and our national governments, show the will and find the money.” And Pat Lorimer acknowledges it might be pie in the sky, but said: “It is very important pie in the sky. “At the moment people are twiddling their thumbs and thinking about putting a traffic island here or there. “This is radical.” To get behind the new movement email info@ayrdeservesbetter.org.uk. Alternatively attend the next meeting in the Unity Grill, Sandgate on Monday May .Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyrAyr News

title: iconic greek statute double former
story: NewsIconic Greek statute that is the double of former Celtic star John Hartson airport is left to rot at Prestwick AirportCall for action toShareByStephen Houston:,  APR NewsCorrosion on statue of Icarus at entrance to the Prestwick International Aerospace Park."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe eight-foot high statue of Greek legend Icarus may be rotting. It is feared either below par casting or a low quality bronze may be causing problems for Icarus. For the past  years the bronze sculpture has adorned the entrance to the Scottish International Aerospace Park at Prestwick. Thousands of drivers pass him every day - and some think he’s a double for former Celtic striker John Hartson. It was commissioned by the now defunct Enterprise Ayrshire and created by the firm where Kelpies sculptor Andy Scott was lead designer. An expert who brought his fears for the sculpture to the Ayrshire Post said: “This should not be happening and my eye can also see cracks that have obviously had some filler work done. “This should not be happening. Good bronze should last without issues for generations. I just wonderon a cost basis the foundry used low quality bronze.” Untrained eyes can see rust developing on the back of Icarus’s wings and on the globe he stands on. Between his feet the surface seems dimpled and stained. One theory is it could be bronze disease, similar to what rust is on iron-based material. The matrix of copper and tin that forms bronze is attacked by hydrochloric acid which can combine with chloride in sea water. On most days Icarus is hit by salty moist air from the sea just half a mile away. In Greek mythology Icarus flew too close to the sun and his wax wings melted. He fell into the sea and drowned. An academic at Brown University at Rhode Island said: “If left untreated, bronze disease will continue to eat away at the metal to the point of complete destruction of the artact.” A study into the condition of Icarus is now to take place. A spokeswoman for Scottish Enterprise said: “The statue at Prestwick Airport was commissioned some  years ago by the local enterprise company, Enterprise Ayrshire. “We have instructed an inspection of the statue and remedial work will be undertakenrequired.” Icarus sculptor Andy Scott now lives in the US and was keen to look at images of him. He said: “Icarus was sculpted by my former company Scott Associates Sculpture  Design and I was lead sculptor. “It was cast in bronze by Beltane Studios in Peebles. It was based, I remember, on a design drawn by a local school pupil. I’ve not personally seen the sculpture for some time. Last time I did it looked just fine. Bronze does not rust. It patinates with time, and the color does alter in the environment.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnJohn HartsonPrestwick AirportUniversities and CollegesEducationAyr

title: one man citizens advice bureau
story: NewsThe one-man citizens advice bureau has diedJoe Lafferty was a sage of Ayr with his informationShareByEdwin Lawrence:,  APR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt often took Joe Lafferty hours to walk down Ayr High Street. That’s because Joe, who has died aged , was a one-man citizens’ advice bureau. Joe was incredibly well-versed on how local government works. And he knew the right people to contact in a range of agencies, including South Ayrshire Council. In recent years, Joe was best known as chairman of Riverside Tenants and Residents Association. But he was equally weel kent in the Lochside and Wallacetoun areas - working passionately to improve the housing stock. Joe seemed to be involved in everything pertaining to housing and community issues. He worked alongside Shelter, learning about legislation on homelessness. He also had close links with Riverside Evangelical Church and the Salvation Army - respecting the wonderful work they do in the community. Joe was also involved with the John Pollock Centre, the Mainholm Advice Centre and was on the Community Planning Board. He was a member of the late lamented Wallacetoun and Newton Regeneration Forumwhich provided a focal point for five communities in Ayr. Joe Lafferty hailed from Newarthill, Lanarkshire, and was a choirboy in his youth. He loved singing right up to his untimely death, being a member of the Ayrways Choir, which helps people with breathing dficulties. In his late teenage years and throughout his s, Joe worked abroad for much of the time. He was a project manager on building sites in countries including Nigeria and Pakistan. Joe ed to Scotland after his marriage to Jean, and became aware of the need for communities to have a voice. This became the driving force in the second half of his le. David Burns, South Ayrshire Council’s former head of housing, said he was sorry to hear of Joe’s passing. Mr Burns added: “He was a wonderful gentleman, always taking a keen interest wherever he felt there was a benefit for the community orhe felt ideas would have a detrimental impact on people. “He also made sure I kept my feet on the ground and often said, ‘Don’t change your ability to listen to the community boy, and you’ll do just rightly.” Joe was highly thought of by many senior SAC managers, and often engaged in banter with them, to make his point. Colleague and friend Pauline Mackie said of Joe: other. “He was never a man who shied away from his own past mistakes and was always very courteous and generous about others as well. He was never a man to bare a grudge. “His wisdom and knowledge along with his sense of humour made him legendary . People were drawn to him even though it meant not getting much of a word in once he got started. He was always courteous and never lost his sense of humour. “Joe also believed in sharing the knowledge he had gleaned over  years, believing knowledge would empower people and communities.” Pauline added: “ Joe, myself and Jackie Lennon considered ourselves the Three Musketeers in the Wallacetoun and Newton Regeneration Forum. “I believe we did make a dference to a lot of people, but sadly the project came to an end.” Joe’s funeral service will be held at noon at Masonhill Crematorium on April  - which would have been his st birthday. He is survived by Jean and their sons, Jack and Jamie, of whom he was immensely proud, and who, like their dad, have worked abroad.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr News

And relieved Jacqui took to Twitter today to share a picture of her swolen wrist picked up in the directorsapos box.  She joked: In the excitement at the end of the game last night, I whacked my wrist on metal bar in directorsapos box. Bruise coming up nicely. But worth it. story: NewsWellswood is property of the weekNeighbouring homes have sold for £, or moreShareByStephen Houston:,  APR Updated:,  APR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the lovely villas on the right as you head to the Brig O’ Doon is seeking a new owner. title: youngsters put toes water during
story: NewsYoungsters put toes in the water during historic rowing event on River AyrA little history was made on the River Ayr as a ‘Come and Try Rowing’ event attracted pupils and apprentices from around South Ayrshire.ShareByPaul Behan:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsPictured are the group during their rowing taster session on the River Ayr "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround  young adults from Prestwick Academy, Kyle Academy, Belmont Academy, Marr College, GE Caledonian and UWS Ayr, took to the water and had a splashing great time. The event involved a successful partnership between South Ayrshire Council, Scottish Rowing, University of West of Scotland and Ayrshire coastal rowing clubs. And it’s believed to be the first time in  years that an organised water-based activity has taken place on the River Ayr. The event was designed to encourage young people to interact safely with the river and get fit and active at the same time. Many of the participants will be undertaking Duke of Edinburgh Gold Awards in the summer and this event was the perfect warm-up. All the young adults were given a safety briefing by representatives from Scottish Rowing, the council and South Ayrshire coastal rowing clubs. They were then allocated their equipment before the group all had the opportunity to try out a single scull, open canoe and a costal boat, setting off along an m course. During the day they all received expert tuition from experienced rowers and instructors. Belmont Academy pupil Alex Crooks, aged , said: “It was something new, a new experience. “I’m doing canoeing for my Duke of Edinburgh award, so it’s about getting experience of the water and the river. I enjoyed it.” Ben Gilmour, aged , a pupil at Prestwick Academy, said: “It was good. “We get out and do free things and it’s good way to spend your time, instead of playing the X-Box! “I do sailing and I do figure skating but I’ve never come out and done loads of watersports . “This has been good and you get to meet new people as well.” It’s hoped that the programme will spark renewed interest in rowing and watersports, given the River Ayr’s proximity to Ayr Academy. Backing the event was the RNLI , who through their Respect the Water campaign, were able to reinforce the key messages about staying safe. The participants were also given a waterproof mobile phone cover, along with literature about water safety, as a thank-you for taking part. Tess Crooks who goes to Belmont Academy said: “It was a fun and enjoyable day, I would like to do more and get to learn new skills on the water.” Ryan Matthews, an apprentice from GE Caledonian, said: “It was a very enjoyable experience and good training for my DofE Gold canoeing expedition later in the summer. “It also made me realise the fitness required for this type of activity and how I need to get fitter.” Councillor William Grant, Children and Young People Portfolio Holder for South Ayrshire Council, said: “South Ayrshire has outstanding natural resources available to everyone. “This is a great way for young people to explore nature, increase their confidence and learn new skills at the same time. “We need to respect all our waterways but rivers should also be enjoyed and the young people taking part clearly had a great time thanks to the expert supervision.” Vincent McWhirter, RNLI Volunteer Community Safety Officer said: “We have  miles of coast line from Barassie to Ballantrae with four main rivers and numerous lochs all of which are very attractive but can also be potentially dangerous, so it was really worthwhile to teach the young people new skills and at the same time learn about the hazards but in a fun way.” If you are interested in taking up rowing, you can contact Scottish Rowing https:www.scottish-rowing.org.uk , Ayrshire Coastal Rowing Clubs: Troon Coastal Rowing https:en-gb.facebook pg TroonCoastalRowingClub posts , Prestwick Coastal Rowing https:www.prestwicksailingclub prestwick-coastal-rowing-club , Carrick Coastal Rowing www.carrickcoastalrowing.org, Girvan Coastal Rowing girvan.rowing@btinternetLike us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: borderers-told-to-prepare-for-euro-election
story: BORDERERS are being advised to prepare for a European Parliament election, despite the UK voting to leave the European Union almost three years ago.Theresa May secured a Brexit deadline extension last week, with the UKrsquos departure delayed until October .However, this deal is conditional upon the UK participating in the European parliamentary election in May.Unless MPs back a withdrawal agreement, which currently looks unlikely, an election to nominate MEPs will be held across the country on Thursday, May .Scottish Borders Council is making plans to ensure the smooth delivery of the poll, with a count scheduled for Sunday, May .Should the election take place, six MEPs will be elected to represent Scotland in the European Parliament.Tracey Logan, Local Returning Officer for the Scottish Borders count, said: ldquoWhile it is still possible that this election will not take place in the UK, we have to be prepared and take all necessary steps to ensure that, should it happen, all aspects of the election run accurately and efficiently.ldquoGiven the relatively short timescale, it is particularly important that people are aware of the dates for voter registration, for requesting or changing postal or proxy votes and when postal votes will be issued as this could impact on those who will be away prior to and over election day on  May.ldquoFor those who do receive a postal vote, Irsquod ask that these are ed as soon as practical.ldquoNot only does this ensure that your vote counts, it also helps speed up the count process as all verication can be completed in advance.The deadline for voter registration is midnight on May  and the deadline for postal vote applications is pm on May .Anyone wishing to appoint a proxy to cast a vote on their behalf has until pm on May  to arrange this and voters hoping to change an existing postal or proxy vote have until pm on May .Borderers are eligible to vote in the European Parliamentary Election provided they are  or over on election day and are a British, Irish or qualying Commonwealth citizen permanently living in the UK, or a citizen of the Republic of Ireland or certain Commonwealth countries and are resident in the UK.Citizens of the European Unionwho wish to vote in this election in Scotland need to complete a separate application to vote, accompanied by a declaration stating that they will vote only in the UK.You can register online at www.gov.uk register-to-vote or by contacting the Electoral Registration Officer on ero@scotborders.gov.uk or  .The necessary paperwork to arrange to vote by post or proxy can be downloaded from www.scotborders.gov.uk registertovote or can be obtained from the Electoral Registration Officer.

title: mini-revival-at-this-years-festival-of-motoring

part of the celebrations was a screening of the classic s film The Italian Job.Around  guests packed into Tower Mill for the launch.In honour of the th anniversary of the release of The Italian Job, the theme of this yearrsquos Festival of Motoring will be lsquoYear of the Minirsquo.Thirlestane Castle will once again welcome vintage car enthusiasts from across Scotland for the event on June .BVAC have including a Classic Mini Cooper Raffle in aid of My Namersquo Doddie Foundation, a Big Mini Cram record-breaking attempt, a special Italian Job display, and surprise celebrity guests for the Classic will celebrate  years of the Mini.ldquoAnd in another birthday celebration, quite remarkably, the Italian Job film will be exactly  years old at this yearrsquos show on the June .ldquoIt is
